text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.22.7, Mail and Transportation Management, Household Goods.

IRM 1.22.7.1(1), Purpose, removed ″to assure quality service for employees and reduce government costs″; (2) Audience, removed ″especially those″; added (5) Primary Stakeholder information per Internal Control Requirements; added (6) Program Goals information per Internal Control Requirements, relocated ″To assure quality service for employees and reduce government costs″

1.22.7.1.3, Roles and Responsibilities, formerly IRM 1.22.7.2, Responsibilities, renamed and per IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Address Management and Internal Controls; (1) replaced “BFC” “CFO Relocation Coordinator”; (2) ﬁrst bullet, added link to IRM 1.32.12, Relocation Travel sixth bullet, added “Reviews changes to the IRM 1.32.12, Relocation Travel Guide, as CFO”; (3) Reworded ﬁrst sentence from “The travel staff of the CFO as the Relocation is responsible to” to “The CFO as the Relocation Coordinator is responsible to″

1.22.7.1.6, Frequently used Terms and Acronyms, added per IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Address and Internal Controls, former IRM 1.22.7.1.3, Acronyms, information relocated to replaced “Cost” with “Commuted” in the deﬁnition for CRS; added new information

IRM 1.22.7.1.7, Related Resources, formerly IRM 1.22.7.2, References, renamed and renumbered per IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Address Management and Internal Controls; (1) removed ﬁrst bullet “41 CFR102-117 subpart G” and fourth bullet “FTR Chapter 302, Relocation Allowance” and relocated information to new IRM 1.22.7.1.2, Authority

IRM 1.22.7.2, Actual Expense Method (AEM), formerly 1.22.7.3, Actual Expense Method (AEM), renumbered per IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Address Management and Internal Controls; all subsequent sections renumbered accordingly
IRM 1.22.7.5, Employee Counseling, formerly IRM 1.22.7.6, Employee Counseling, (2) “guides” with “guide”, removed 2nd bullet “Employee Guide to Shipping Your Household Goods

IRM 1.22.7.6.3, Storage, formerly 1.22.7.7.3, Storage, (1) replaced “storage in transit (SIT)” with “Storage In Transit (SIT)”; (1)a. reworded “Initial temporary storage expense is limited to 60 days, but may be extended in 60-day increments to 150 days upon the employee’s reasonable written request” to “Initial temporary storage expense is limited to 60 days, under certain circumstances an extension

IRM 1.22.7.7.3, Paperwork Preparation, formerly IRM 1.22.7.8.3, Paperwork Preparation, (1) replaced “The CFO travel staff” with “ The CFO Relocation Coordinator”, replaced “Form 4253-A, Authorization for Basic Moving Expenses, in the possession of the travel staff” with “the relocation authorization for basic moving expenses”
IRM 1.22.7.7.4, Quality Control, formerly IRM 1.22.7.8.4, Quality Control, (1) replaced “send it to the Relocation Coordinator for submission to GSA” with “submit it to GSA”
1.22.7.8, Authorized Cost Limits and Reimbursement to the Government, formerly IRM 1.22.7.9, Cost Limits and Reimbursement to the Government, replaced “old” with “previous”

IRM 1.22.7.10, Review of Carrier Vouchers, formerly IRM 1.22.7.11, Review of Carrier Vouchers, (1) replaced “pre-audit” with “prepayment-auditor”, replaced “The PTP Section sends the vouchers electronically to the BFC for payment” with “After the PTP Section processes the vouchers electronically to the BFC, the CFO relocation technician will process for payment”
IRS Employees
Table of Contents
Goods

) Purpose: This section provides guidance and procedures for the IRS tion Coordinator in administering the IRS Relocation Program to assure Scope and service for employees and reduce government costs. (
) Audience: All IRS employees who administer the IRS Relocation Program. (
) Policy Owner: The Chief Financial Officer (CFO) is responsible for the movement of Household Goods (HHG) and personal effects of IRS employees. (
) Program Owner: Distribution Requirements is the program office for overseeing and providing guidance for the IRS Relocation Program. (

) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders in the HHG program: • IRS Personnel authorized for HHG shipments • IRS Business Units • Pre-payment Auditor • Chief Financial Officer • Postal and Transport Policy (
) Program Goals: The goals of the Household Goods program are to: • Assure quality service for relocating employees • Reduce government transportation costs (

) The General Services Administration (GSA) establishes the relocation policies and procedures. The program provides economical and efficient service to federal executive agency employees. The basic of the program are cost comparisons, carrier approval, price negotiation carrier performance measurements. (

) Household Goods (HHG) are the personal effects of IRS employees and dependents. HHG include household furnishings, equipment, appliances, furniture, clothing, books and similar personal property which belong to the employees or members of their immediate family. There are limits to what employees can ship as part of their HHG. (
) IRS can authorize the transportation of Privately Owned Vehicles (POV) in connection with an authorized relocation allowance. (

) The management of the IRS policy and procedures of HHG movement and general liaison with the GSA is the responsibility of Media and Publications and (M&P)/Distribution (D)/Distribution Requirements Branch (DRB)/Postal and Transport Policy (PTP) Section. The PTP section is also responsible for providing policy guidance to the CFO Relocation Coordinator and general sistance operations. (

) The Pre-Payment Auditor receives the invoices from the moving companies and reviews the invoices for accuracy and costing. (
) PTP Program Manager accesses the Pre-payment Auditor’s website to invoices for review. (
) PTP Program Manager signs the invoices and uploads to the Pre-Auditor website. (
) Beckley Finance accesses the signed invoices and make payments.

Term Deﬁnition Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Codiﬁcation of the general and permanent rules published in the Federal Register by the executive departments and agencies of the Federal Govern- ment. House Hold Goods (HHG) The personal effects of IRS employees and their dependents. Internal Revenue Bill of Lading (IRBL) Authorizes the Carrier to coordinate and transport the shipments. ) The CFO Relocation Coordinator selects the carrier from the GSA cost parison listing, arranges for carrier service, prepares Form
, Internal Expense Method Revenue Service Bill of Lading-Privately Owned Personal Property (IRBL), assists the employee with claims against the carrier or Government for loss damage. (
) Under CRS, the transferred employee arranges for shipping HHG. The IRS reimburses the employee according to distance and weight as listed in the Rate System CRS published by the GSA. (
) The employee is responsible for arranging for the shipment to be weighed obtain weight certiﬁcates. (
) CRS can be less costly to the IRS when there is excessive packing, crating, other accessorial or third-party charges using the AEM. (
) When an employee is authorized to self-move, they will be reimbursed for of pocket expenses. This amount will not exceed what the IRS will pay Method AEM. (
) The self-move method can be beneﬁcial when items of extraordinary value require high insurance, special handling of collectibles is necessary, or other unique circumstances exist. (

) The CFO Relocation Coordinator travel staff provides employee counselling all aspects of the move. Transferred employees are given a “Household Counselling Counselling Checklist” and a checklist of “Things to Do Before Your Move.” (

) Employees can use the following self-help guide published by GSA: • Your Rights and Responsibilities When You Move at: gsa.gov/travel/agency-services/relocation/household-goods-transpportation Note: On a direct cost comparison, CRS or self-move options may appear less costly. But, due to the manual labor in moving HHG, the employee is ex- posed to possible personal injury and loss of time on the job. For this rea- son, CRS and self-moves can be denied by the CFO as not in the IRS’ interest. (

) The selected carrier must do an on-site pre-move survey at least three days prior to the actual move. The employee can allow a shorter time if needed. The IRBL issuing officer will authorize in writing a telephonic survey. A copy of the pre-move survey must be given to the employee and the CFO Relocation Coordinator. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. ) A carrier’s liability limit is determined by the shipment valuation or released (
) value. Carriers do not offer insurance. Shipment Valuation and (
) Accessorial service is supplemental to basic transportation and is provided Accessorial Services the carrier at an additional cost.
) Valuation is stated on the IRBL before it is issued to the carrier. (

) IRS authorizes employee’s goods to be shipped at Full Value Protection. Shipment Valuation guarantees either replacement of articles lost or damaged while in the custody, reimbursement for full replacement cost, or satisfactory repairs. De- preciation is not applied. Full Value Protection requires a shipment be at a value of at least $
or $

per pound whichever is greater. If the employee request increases valuation charges above that amount, the addi- tional charges is the responsibility of the employee. Note: All articles identiﬁed as extremely expensive or valuable should be (in writing) by an accredited appraiser prior to the move. Claims for loss of these articles will be disallowed by the Government or the carrier due to extraordinary value. The employee should be advised to take these items with their person if practical, or ship separately with commercial insurance coverage.
) Accessorial Services include those extra services performed by the carrier. (
) These services include stair carry, shuttle service, waiting time, appliance

IRS authorizes employee’s goods to be shipped at Full Value Protection. This guarantees either replacement of articles lost or damaged while in the carrier’s custody, reimbursement for full replacement cost, or satisfactory repairs. De- preciation is not applied. Full Value Protection requires a shipment be declared at a value of at least $
or $
per pound whichever is greater. If the employee request increases valuation charges above that amount, the addi- tional charges is the responsibility of the employee.

All articles identiﬁed as extremely expensive or valuable should be appraised (in writing) by an accredited appraiser prior to the move. Claims for loss of these articles will be disallowed by the Government or the carrier due to their extraordinary value. The employee should be advised to take these items with their person if practical, or ship separately with commercial insurance coverage.

SIT is authorized when the employee cannot immediately move into the residence at the new location. SIT at destination is preferred but may be authorized at origin or an intermediate point. Initial temporary storage expense is limited to

employee’s responsibility when SIT limits are exceeded. The carrier invoice IRS for these charges. The IRS, in turn, will recover the amount from the employee. (

) The shipment weight is determined by weighing the moving van before after loading, and the difference or net weight is the billed weight. the Shipment (

) The carrier must use a scale which will permit the employee to observe weighing. The moving employee should protect him/herself and the IRS overcharging by going to the scale and observing the weighing of the before and after loading the shipment. (

) The empty moving van should initially be weighed with the fuel tanks on vehicle full, and the vehicle must contain all the equipment needed in the transportation of the shipment. The driver should not be in the truck or on scale. (

) If the employee is not satisﬁed with the accuracy of the weight, the carrier must, upon the employee’s and/or IRS’ timely request, again weigh the before and after delivery. The billing weight shall be the reweigh weight less of whether it is higher or lower than the initial weighing. There is no charge for reweighing. (

) A carrier representative will make a written inventory of articles as they being loaded and make a notation on the inventory showing the condition Inventory the employee’s furniture and other goods. The employee or the representative should be present to ensure that the description of the is accurate. (
) If loss or damage is noticed on delivery, entries must be made on both carrier delivery receipt and inventory forms. The driver must sign these to acknowledge the loss or damage. (
) High value items must be listed on a separate “high value” inventory. (
) Selecting the carrier, facilitating necessary carrier services related to the preparing documents accurately and monitoring quality control are the components of Move Coordination.

The driver should not be in the truck or scale. If the employee is not satisﬁed with the accuracy of the weight, the must, upon the employee’s and/or IRS’ timely request, again weigh the before and after delivery. The billing weight shall be the reweigh weight less of whether it is higher or lower than the initial weighing. There is no charge for reweighing. A carrier representative will make a written inventory of articles as they being loaded and make a notation on the inventory showing the the employee’s furniture and other goods. The employee or the representative should be present to ensure that the description of the is accurate. If loss or damage is noticed on delivery, entries must be made on both carrier delivery receipt and inventory forms. The driver must sign these to acknowledge the loss or damage. High value items must be listed on a separate “high value” inventory. When contacted, carriers should be told the move is authorized under the GSA HHG Tender of Service. Initial information given to the carrier includes:
After accepting the move, the carrier is given this additional information:
When the move is complete, the moving employee must complete GSA Form 3080, Household Goods Carrier Evaluation Report, and submit it to GSA.
Mail and Transportation (

) The employee may choose to move via another carrier and still move on an IRBL. The employee must notify the CFO Relocation Coordinator stating that they will pay the difference, if higher, between the charges of their selected carrier and the carrier recommended by the travel staff. (
) If the moving employee is advised to move under the CRS, the move will be reimbursed for the CRS amount shown on the GSA cost comparison. (

) Intrastate or short distance moves under the CRS require analysis. If it is de- termined that the actual charges for the move will not exceed the CRS, the employee may move using an IRBL. IRS will pay all authorized charges these circumstances. (
) Funds for expenses are issued in one lump sum amount under the CRS. If employee’s expenses exceed the amount allotted, the employee must pay difference. (

) If the moving employee elects the self-move method, reimbursement will be actual expenses incurred and documented (e.g., truck rental, gas, oil, equipment, hired labor), limited to the cost of the carrier listed on the GSA comparison with whom IRS would have scheduled the move. (
) If the moving employee selects their own carrier and elects not to move via IRBL, reimbursement will be limited to the computed charges of the carrier ommended by the Relocation Coordinator. (
) If HHG are lost or damaged while in transit or in storage, IRS employees should request claim forms from the carrier. (
) IRS employees can ﬁle loss or damage claims with the carrier and IRS simul- taneously. The Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) allows a HHG carrier

days to offer a compromise settlement. IRS may make a settlement in a shorter period of time. IRS settlements are based on replacement costs depreciation of damaged or lost items. Carrier settlement offers are based on full replacement value. For that reason, employees should wait for the carrier settlement offer before ﬁling a claim against the IRS. If the carrier’s does not cover the full amount of the claim, any funds received from the will reduce the amount of the claim against the IRS by a like amount. (
) The IRS will underwrite loss or damage to HHG to the extent that the posses- sion of the property is determined to be reasonable, useful or proper. (
) The procedures for ﬁling claim with the Treasury Department for personal property that is lost or damaged incident to service are contained in Treasury Directive
, (TD
) “Policies and Procedures For Employees ‘Claim Loss or Damage to Personal Property Incident to Service’”. Link to TD
href=https://www.treasury.gov/about/role-of-treasury/orders-directives/Pages/td
aspx.
1.22 Mail and Transportation Management

The employee may choose to move via another carrier and still move on an IRBL. The employee must notify the CFO Relocation Coordinator stating that they will pay the difference, if higher, between the charges of their selected carrier and the carrier recommended by the travel staff.
Funds for expenses are issued in one lump sum amount under the CRS. If the employee’s expenses exceed the amount allotted, the employee must pay the
The IRS will underwrite loss or damage to HHG to the extent that the sion of the property is determined to be reasonable, useful or proper.

) The carrier must send all HHG vouchers to the IRS prepayment audit contrac- tor. Vouchers are thoroughly screened for discrepancies to ensure that the IRS of Carrier has been properly invoiced by the carrier. The contractor forwards the voucher electronically to the PTP Section for ﬁnal review and certiﬁcation for payment. After PTP Section processes the vouchers electronically to the BFC, the CFO technician will process for payment.
